Chapter 6, Part 2: Distinguishing the Noble Ones. Thus far, the two gates of entering cultivation have been explained. Through these two gates, the mind attains concentration.
Having attained mental concentration, what else should one cultivate?
Verse:
Relying on the already cultivated and accomplished tranquility, one cultivates the foundations of mindfulness for insight.
Observing the body, feelings, mind, and dharmas with their specific and general characteristics.
The wisdom of self-nature, hearing, etc., the other characteristics and objects,
Are said to arise in sequence, only four are taught to counteract delusions.
Discussion:
Relying on the already cultivated and accomplished supreme Å›amatha, one cultivates the four foundations of mindfulness for vipaÅ›yanÄ.
How does one cultivate the four foundations of mindfulness?ğŸ”½It means observing the body, feelings, mind, and dharmas with their specific and general characteristics.
The specific natures of the body, feelings, mind, and dharmas are called their specific characteristics.
The common characteristics are that all conditioned dharmas are impermanent, all defiled dharmas are suffering, and all dharmas are empty and without self.
The intrinsic nature of the body is the great elements and the form derived from them.
The intrinsic nature of feeling and mind is as indicated by their own names.
The intrinsic nature of dharmas is the dharmas other than the three [above].

It is said that when one contemplates the body in samÄdhi, observing each atom and moment separately, it is called the fulfillment of mindfulness of the body. The characteristics of the fulfillment of the other three [mindfulnesses] should be understood accordingly.
What are the intrinsic natures of the four establishments of mindfulness?
These four establishments of mindfulness each have three intrinsic natures, due to the distinctions of intrinsic nature, association, and object.

The establishment of mindfulness of intrinsic nature takes wisdom as its intrinsic nature. This wisdom is of three kinds, namely, that accomplished through hearing, etc. It is also called the three kinds of establishments of mindfulness.
The establishment of mindfulness of association takes the remaining associated [dharmas] as its intrinsic nature.
The establishment of mindfulness of objects takes the dharmas that are the objects of wisdom as its intrinsic nature.
How do we know that the intrinsic nature is wisdom and not something else?
A sÅ«tra says:
Mindfulness of the body is called the application of mindfulness to the body.
The other three are also like this.
The term â€œapplication of mindfulnessâ€ refers only to the essence of wisdom, because without wisdom there is no function of application of mindfulness.
Why is wisdom given the name of application of mindfulness?
The VaibhÄá¹£ikas say:
Because mindfulness increases in this category.
The meaning is that wisdom is able to function by the power of mindfulness, just as an ax breaks wood by the power of the wedge.

In reality, one should say that wisdom causes mindfulness to abide, and for that reason wisdom is given the name of application of mindfulness, because it clearly remembers what is observed by wisdom. For this reason, Aniruddha said:
If one is able to apply mindfulness to the body and observe the body, then mindfulness of the body can abide, and so on at length.
The World Honored One also said:
If one applies mindfulness to the body and observes the body, then mindfulness abides without error.
However, there is a sÅ«tra that says:
Why is the arising of these four applications of mindfulness?
Why is their cessation?
Because the aggregates of food, contact, name-and-form, and attention increase, they cause the body, feeling, thought, and dharmas to increase.
Because the aggregates of food, contact, name-and-form, and attention decrease, they cause the body, feeling, thought, and dharmas to decrease.
You should know that what they say is the object of the mindfulness abode, because mindfulness is able to abide in it.
Moreover, the specific names of the mindfulness abodes are due to the differences in their objects, self, other, both, and continuity.
Each of the four mindfulness abodes is of three kinds. These four mindfulness abodes are said to arise in sequence.
Why do they arise?
Their sequence is like this.
Because the coarsest object should be observed first, or because craving for desire realm objects occurs in relation to the body, the observation of the four mindfulness abodes begins with the body.

However, craving for the body is due to delight in feeling, delight in feeling is due to an undisciplined mind, and the undisciplined mind is due to the non-eradication of the afflictions. Therefore, the observation of feeling, etc., is in this sequence.

These four foundations of mindfulness counteract the four kinds of perversions, namely, regarding the impure as pure, regarding suffering as happiness, regarding impermanence as permanence, and regarding nonself as self. Therefore there are only four foundations of mindfulness, neither more nor less.
Among the four, the first three have only unmixed objects, while the objects of the fourth are both mixed and unmixed.
If one only contemplates dharmas, it is called unmixed objects. If one generally observes the two, three, or four objects such as the body, it is called mixed objects.
Having thus cultivated the mixed objects of the foundations of mindfulness such as the body, what else is there to cultivate?
Verse:
Dwelling in the foundation of mindfulness of dharmas, one generally observes the four objects,
Cultivating the aspects of impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and nonself.
Commentary:

The practitioner dwelling in the foundation of mindfulness of dharmas with mixed objects generally observes the four objects such as the body and cultivates the four aspects, namely impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and nonself.
Having cultivated this contemplation, what wholesome roots are produced?
Verse:
From this, the heat dharma arises, fully contemplating the four noble truths,
Cultivating the sixteen aspects, the next arising peak is also so.
Thus, these two wholesome roots are all first dharmas and later four.
Next, patience is only the mindfulness of dharmas, the lower and middle grades are the same as the peak,
The upper only contemplates the suffering of desire, one aspect in one instant,
The supreme worldly dharma is also so, all are wisdom, excluding attainment.
The treatise says:
Cultivating the total contemplation of the common characteristics of the mindfulness of dharmas gradually matures up to the highest grade.
After this mindfulness, the first wholesome root of the factors leading to penetration arises, named the heat dharma.

This dharma is established as heat, named the heat dharma, which is the prior sign of the fire of the holy path that burns the firewood of afflictions, and is named heat because it is the prior sign of fire.
Because this heat wholesome root has a long duration, it can fully contemplate the objects of the four noble truths, and can fully cultivate the sixteen aspects.
Contemplating the noble truth of suffering cultivates four aspects:
impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and non-self.
Contemplating the noble truth of the cause of suffering cultivates four aspects:
cause, accumulation, production, and condition.
Contemplating the noble truth of the cessation of suffering cultivates four aspects:
cessation, tranquility, excellence, and separation.
Contemplating the noble truth of the path cultivates four aspects:
path, suchness, practice, and exit.
The distinctions in these aspects will be discussed later.
When the roots of good from this heat gradually increase to the point of fulfillment, there arises a root of good called the summit, which is given a different name because it is even more excellent.
Among the roots of good that can be shaken, this dharma is the most excellent, like the summit of a person, so it is called the summit.
Or, because this is the boundary between advancing and retreating, like the peak of a mountain, it is called the summit.
This also, like heat, fully contemplates the four truths and is able to fully cultivate the sixteen aspects.
In the two kinds of roots of goodness of heat and summit, when first establishing the feet, there is only the application of mindfulness to dharmas.
For what meaning is it called first establishing the feet?

It means that according to which root of goodness, with the sixteen aspects, first treads the traces of the four noble truths, when later progressing, it is equipped with the four applications of mindfulness.
The previously attained are not manifest, because one does not give rise to a reverent mind towards them.

This summit root of goodness, in the lower, middle, and upper grades, gradually increases and grows, reaching the time of completion, there is a root of goodness that arises called the dharma of patience, because in the principle of the four truths, being able to endure and accept it, this is the most excellent.
Moreover, in this stage of patience, there is no falling back, therefore it is called the dharma of patience.
This patience root of goodness, establishing the feet and progressing, are all the application of mindfulness to dharmas, different from the previous.

However, this dharma of patience has lower, middle, and upper, the lower and middle two grades are the same as the summit dharma, namely, fully observing the realm of the four noble truths and being able to fully cultivate the sixteen aspects.
The superior variety is different, for it only contemplates the suffering of the realm of desire, because it is adjacent to the supreme worldly state.
On the basis of this interpretation, it is established that the roots of good of heat, etc., are all able to take as objects suffering, etc., of the three realms, because there is no distinction.

That is, the spiritual practitioner, in regard to the aspects of the holy truths such as the counteractive paths of form and the formless, reduces and abbreviates the objects of each aspect of the holy truths, and finally he contemplates the object of the holy truth of suffering of the realm of desire in two moments of thought. This is called the state of medium patience.
Immediately after this state, superior roots of good arise in one moment of thought, and this is called superior patience. Because this root of good does not continue in a series.
Immediately after superior patience, the supreme worldly state arises.

Like superior patience, it takes as object the truth of suffering of the realm of desire and cultivates one aspect, and it is only one moment. Because it is impure, it is called mundane, and because it is the most excellent, it is called supreme.
Because it is the most excellent of impure dharmas in the mundane, it is called the supreme worldly state.
The power of the personâ€™s effort is able to separate from the cause of the same species and attract the arising of the holy path, and for this reason it is called supreme.

The four kinds of roots of goodness, such as heat, etc., are by nature mindfulness, and therefore all have wisdom as their substance. If they are accompanied by auxiliaries, they are all of the nature of the five aggregates.
However, one must exclude the acquisition of these roots of goodness, because one must not allow the roots of goodness such as heat, etc., of holy ones to appear again.

When the dharma of heat is first established, one cultivates in the present and future four of the four foundations of mindfulness that have as their object the three truths, and one cultivates in the present and future four of the four aspects.

When the foundation of mindfulness that has as its object the truth of cessation is present, one cultivates in the present and future one of the four foundations of mindfulness and one cultivates in the present and future four of the four aspects.
Because this nature has not been acquired previously, and one is able to cultivate it only when one is in the same stage.

When it is subsequently increased, one cultivates in the present and future four of the four foundations of mindfulness that have as their object the three truths, and one cultivates in the present and future sixteen of the four aspects.

When the dharma-contemplation of the truth of cessation is present, one cultivates four in the future. When one of the aspects is present, sixteen are cultivated in the future, because one of this nature has already attained the different kinds in the past and is able to cultivate them.

When the summit first becomes firmly established, when the dharma-contemplation of the four truths is present, one cultivates four in the future. When one of the aspects is present, sixteen are cultivated in the future.
When it is later enhanced, when one of the contemplations of the three truths is present, one cultivates four in the future. When one of the aspects is present, sixteen are cultivated in the future.
When the dharma-contemplation of the truth of cessation is present, one cultivates four in the future. When one of the aspects is present, sixteen are cultivated in the future.

When the patience first becomes firmly established and later enhanced, when the dharma-contemplation of the four truths is present, one cultivates four in the future. When one of the aspects is present, sixteen are cultivated in the future.
However, when the object is abbreviated in enhancement, one does not cultivate those aspects that are abbreviated in the object.

The supreme worldly dharmas take the truth of suffering of the desire realm as their object. The dharma of mindfulness is cultivated in the present and four are cultivated in the future. One of the aspects is cultivated in the present and four are cultivated in the future, because there is no distinction and because it resembles the path of seeing.
The characteristics and essence of the wholesome roots that are produced have already been explained. Next, the meaning of their distinctions should be explained.
Verse:
These are all accomplished by cultivation,
in six stages, two or seven, based on the body of the desire realm, nine,
two are obtained by women and men, the fourth is also so for women.
The noble ones abandon them by losing the stage, ordinary beings by death.
The first two are also abandoned by regression. Based on the original, one necessarily sees the truth.
After abandoning, one obtains what was not previously obtained. The two abandonments are by nature non-obtainment.
The treatise says:
These four excellent wholesome roots of heat, summit, patience, and supreme worldly dharmas are called the factors conducive to penetration.
In what sense are they established as the factors conducive to penetration?
Determination is the determination of that which is to be cut off, and selection is the selection of that which is to be selected.
Determination and selection refer to the holy path, because the holy path can cut off doubt and can distinguish the characteristics of the four truths.

Division refers to the division of sections. This statement intends to show that what is in accordance with is only a part of the path of insight, because it is a part of the selection of that which is to be cut off. Therefore, it obtains the name of the part of the selection of that which is to be cut off.

These four are the conditions that attract the part of the selection of that which is to be cut off, because they benefit that which is in accordance with it. Therefore, they obtain the name of that which is in accordance with it. Therefore, this is called that which is in accordance with the selection of that which is to be cut off.
These four kinds are all accomplished through cultivation, not accomplished through hearing or contemplation, because they are only the stage of equipoise.
Among the four, the first two are categorized as inferior, because they are both movable and still subject to retrogression.
Patience is categorized as middling, because it is superior to the first two and has the supreme worldly dharmas as its superior.
The supreme worldly dharmas are exclusively categorized as superior.
These four kinds of roots of goodness all depend on six stages, namely the four meditations, the stage of preliminary concentration, and the intermediate meditation.
They do not exist in the realm of desire, because they lack equipoise.
The other upper stages also do not have them, because they are the retinue of the path of insight.
Also, because the mind of the formless realm does not take the realm of desire as an object, the realm of desire must be completely known and eliminated first.

These four roots of good are able to induce the retribution of the five aggregates of the realm of form as the cause of completion, but they are not able to attract, because they turn their backs on existence.
Or the word or indicates that there are two different opinions, namely, that the two, heat and summit,
The Venerable Subhagupta says:

These four roots of good are based on the body of desire, the nine places of humans and celestials, excluding the northern continent of Kuru. The first three roots of good are initially produced in the three continents, and later, in the places of rebirth in the heavens, they also continue to appear.
The fourth root of good is also produced in the heavens, because it is without beginning or end and is only a single moment.
These four roots of good are only based on males and females. The first three are both obtained by males and females. The fourth is also obtained in two ways by the female body.
Based on the male, only the roots of good of the male body are obtained, because the cessation not due to deliberation of the female body has already been obtained.
When a sage falls from this stage, he loses this root of good. The phrase â€œfalls from this stageâ€ indicates that he moves and is born in a higher stage.
When an ordinary being falls from this stage, he does not fall from it, but he does lose the common lot of beings in this stage and necessarily loses this root of good.

The first two roots of good are also lost through falling away. One falls away through death and loses them, but only ordinary beings lose them, not sages. One falls away through losing the stage, but only sages lose them, not ordinary beings.
Ordinary beings also do not fall away from forbearance and the supreme worldly dharmas.

When one generates the roots of good such as heat in dependence on the fundamental meditations, he definitely realizes the noble truths in this life, because his mind is extremely sharp in its disgust with the cycle of death and rebirth.
If one has already lost them and later regains them, what he obtains is definitely not what he has already lost.
This is so because, like the prÄtimoká¹£a precepts, they are not the result of mature cultivation and are accomplished through great effort.
If one has already obtained the roots of good such as heat, he loses them through the passage of time.

If one encounters a good teacher who explains the Dharma well, one will then give rise to the summit and so on. If one does not encounter [a good teacher], one will return to cultivating from the beginning.
Loss and falling away are by nature the non-acquisition of [wholesome roots]. Falling away necessarily involves committing offenses, but loss does not necessarily [involve committing offenses].
What are the benefits of acquiring these wholesome roots?
Verse:
Heat necessarily leads to nirvana, the summit never severs wholesome roots,
Patience does not fall into evil destinies, the first enters the stage of separation.
Commentary:

Among the four wholesome roots, if one attains the stage of heat, although there is falling away, severing of wholesome roots, creating uninterrupted [evil karma], falling into evil destinies, and so on, one does not wander for a long time, and necessarily reaches nirvana.
If so, how is this different from the factors conducive to liberation?
If there are no obstacles, one is close to seeing the truth, because this is the same as the practice of the path of seeing.
If one attains the stage of the summit, although there is falling away and so on, one increases and never severs wholesome roots.

Although one may lose the state of an ordinary being by dying when one has attained the stage of patience, one does not retrogress in the increase of patience, one does not commit the actions with an immediately successive retribution, and one does not fall into evil destinies.

However, the verse only mentions not falling into evil destinies, and the meaning is already understood as not committing the actions with an immediately successive retribution, because one who commits the actions with an immediately successive retribution must fall into evil destinies.
The stage of patience is without retrogressing, as has already been explained.
This stage does not fall into the various evil destinies because one has already distanced oneself from the actions and passions that lead to them.
If one reaches the stage of patience, one attains the state of non-production with regard to a small number of destinies, births, abodes, bodies, and passions.
Destinies refers to the various evil destinies.
Births refers to birth from eggs and moisture.
Abodes refers to the abodes of non-perception, Uttarakuru, and MahÄbrahmÄ.
Bodies refers to the bodies of eunuchs, hermaphrodites, and those with two organs.
Existence refers to the eighth existence, etc.
Passions refers to the passions that are to be eliminated by the path of insight.

These are obtained in the lower and upper stages as appropriate. That is, in the lower patience one obtains non-production of evil destinies, and one obtains non-production of the rest up to the upper patience.
Although one obtains the supreme worldly dharmas and abides in the stage of ordinary beings, one is able to enter the correct separation from birth.

Although the verse does not mention separation from death and abandonment, since one enters the correct separation from birth without interruption, it is already established by implication that there is no abandonment upon death.
Why is it only this [supreme worldly dharmas] that can enter separation from birth?
Because one has already obtained the non-discriminative cessation of ordinary beings, and because one is able to abandon the nature of ordinary beings like the uninterrupted path.
These four wholesome roots each have three grades, because of the difference in species of Å›rÄvakas and so forth.
If the wholesome roots have already arisen in a certain species, can one be transferred and turn towards another vehicle?
The verse says:
Two Å›rÄvaka species can become buddhas, the other three cannot.
The rhinoceros horn [buddha] has no turning, because he attains enlightenment in one sitting.
The treatise says:

If the family type of the Å›rÄvaka has already produced heat and summit, it is possible for them to transform and attain supreme enlightenment. If they have already obtained the forbearance stage, there is no principle of their becoming Buddhas, because they have already transcended evil destinies.

Bodhisattvas, with the intention of benefiting beings, must go to evil destinies in order to transform beings. Their forbearance stage cannot be turned back, and therefore they definitely have no meaning of attaining Buddhahood.

The three of heat, summit, and forbearance of the Å›rÄvaka family all have the meaning of being able to transform and become pratyekabuddhas, because they are outside the Buddha vehicle and are therefore said to be the rest.
The words â€œpratyekabuddhas and Buddhasâ€ in the verse of Vasubandhu indicate the pratyekabuddha and supreme enlightenment.

The roots of good such as heat all have no meaning of turning and going to another vehicle, because they all take the fourth trance state as their support, and they attain enlightenment of their own vehicle in one sitting.
The fourth trance state is unshakable and extremely clear and sharp samÄdhi, and therefore it can be the support for the pratyekabuddha and supreme enlightenment.
Here, the word â€œenlightenmentâ€ indicates the knowledge of extinction and non-production, which will be explained later, because it is the nature of enlightenment.
As for â€œin one sitting,â€ from the stage of heat up to enlightenment, one does not rise from oneâ€™s seat.
Other masters say:
From the contemplation of impurity, one does not rise from oneâ€™s seat up to enlightenment.
There are other pratyekabuddhas besides the rhinoceros type. It is not denied that those of this type, having generated the first two roots of good, can turn toward another vehicle.
Can one who first cultivates this practice in this life generate the aids to penetration in this life?
No, it is not so.ğŸ”½
How is it?
Verse:
The aids to liberation are quick, liberated in three lives.
Hearing and contemplating, three actions, planted in the three continents of humans.
Commentary:ğŸ”½One who now generates the aids to penetration must have generated the aids to liberation in a previous life.
Those who first plant the aids to liberation are liberated in at most three lives.
That is, the first arising of the aids to penetration, the second arising of the aids to liberation, and the third entry into the noble path and attainment of liberation.
It is like the three stages of planting seeds, seedling growth, and fruit ripening.
The three stages of entering the nature of dharmas, maturation, and liberation are also like this.
It is said that the aids to liberation are only accomplished through hearing and contemplation, and their essence is the three karmas.
Although they are only mental karmas in terms of supremacy, the volition and vows that give rise to bodily and verbal actions are also called aids to liberation.
Even giving one meal or upholding one precept with a deep desire for liberation and the power of vows is called planting the seeds of the aids to liberation.

Planting the aids to liberation is only in the three continents of humans. In other places, there is no disgust and prajÃ±Ä as appropriate, so one encounters the Buddha appearing in the world and plants these wholesome roots.
Other masters say:
One also encounters pratyekabuddhas.
Having already discussed the factors conducive to liberation incidentally, the sequence of entering contemplation is the main topic being discussed.
In this, the various paths of preparation have already been clarified, with the supreme worldly dharmas as their final limit. It should be explained what path arises from this.
Verse:
Immediately after the supreme worldly dharmas, taking the suffering of the desire realm as their object,
The pure dharmas of patience are born. Following patience, dharma knowledge is born.
Next, taking the suffering of the other realms as their objects, the subsequent patience and subsequent knowledge are born.
Taking the truths of origination, cessation, and path as objects, four are born in the same way.
These sixteen minds are called the clear realization of the noble truths.
In general, there are three kinds, namely, seeing, taking as object, and the separate.
The treatise says:

Immediately after the supreme worldly dharmas, taking the noble truth of suffering in the desire realm as their object, there arises the patience of dharma knowledge that is included in the pure realm. This patience is called the patience of dharma knowledge regarding suffering. In order to show that this patience is pure, the subsequent homogeneous cause is taken as the distinguishing characteristic.
This is the cause of the knowledge of dharmas, and is called the receptivity to the knowledge of dharmas, like a tree that bears flowers and fruit.
This is also called entering the certainty of perfection, and is also called entering the certainty of the noble path.
Because this is the first entry into the certainty of perfection, and also the first entry into the certainty of the noble path.
The sutra says that the certainty of perfection refers to nirvana.
Or the word certainty refers to the various noble paths.
Birth refers to afflictions, or faculties that are not yet mature.
Because the noble path can transcend it, it is called leaving birth. It can decisively lead to nirvana, or decisively understand the characteristics of the truths,
Therefore, the various noble paths are given the name certainty. Entering this stage is called entering.
When this receptivity arises, one is given the name noble one. This [receptivity] in the future abandons the nature of ordinary beings.
It is accepted that when this receptivity arises in the future, it has this function, not the others, like a lamp and the characteristics of arising.
Other masters say:

The meaning of the first of the supreme factors of those about to enter abandoning the nature of ordinary beings is not so, because these two are the same in being called mundane dharmas and because they are mutually contradictory.
There is no error, just as one can kill an enemy by striking his shoulder.
Other masters say:
These two abandon together, because they are like the path of no-interruption and the path of liberation.
Immediately after this patience, there is the knowledge of dharmas with regard to the suffering of the realm of desire that is called the knowledge of dharmas with regard to suffering.
You should know that this knowledge is also categorized as pure, because the previous word pure extends to this.

Just as there is patience with regard to dharmas with regard to the object of the holy truth of suffering of the realm of desire, and there is knowledge of dharmas with regard to suffering that arises,

in the same way, immediately after knowledge of dharmas, there is the patience of subsequent knowledge with regard to the object of the holy truth of suffering of the other realms that is called the patience of subsequent knowledge with regard to suffering.
Immediately after this patience, there is the subsequent knowledge with regard to this object that is called the subsequent knowledge with regard to suffering.

Because it is the first to realize the truth of dharmas, it is called knowledge of dharmas. The subsequent knowledge of objects is similar to the preceding, and therefore it is called knowledge of species. Because the subsequent knowledge follows the preceding in realizing objects.

For example, in relation to the truth of suffering, there are four: the receptivity to the knowledge of dharmas and the knowledge of dharmas in the desire realm and elsewhere, and the receptivity to the knowledge of species and the knowledge of species. The same is true for the other three truths, each having four.

That is to say, after the subsequent knowledge of suffering, next there arises the receptivity to the knowledge of dharmas in relation to the object of the noble truth of the accumulation in the desire realm, called the receptivity to the knowledge of dharmas of accumulation.
Immediately after this receptivity, there arises the knowledge of dharmas in relation to the accumulation in the desire realm, called the knowledge of dharmas of accumulation.

Next, there arises the receptivity to the knowledge of species in relation to the object of the noble truth of the accumulation in the other realms, called the receptivity to the knowledge of species of accumulation.

Immediately after this receptivity, there arises the knowledge of species in relation to this object, called the knowledge of species of accumulation.ğŸ”½Next, there arises the receptivity to the knowledge of dharmas in relation to the object of the noble truth of cessation in the desire realm, called the receptivity to the knowledge of dharmas of cessation.
Immediately after this receptivity, there arises the knowledge of dharmas in relation to the cessation in the desire realm, called the knowledge of dharmas of cessation.

Next, with regard to the realm of form and the formless realm, there arises the patience that is knowledge of the class of the truth of cessation, called the patience of knowledge of the class of the truth of cessation.
Immediately after this patience, there arises knowledge of the class of the truth of cessation with regard to the same object, called knowledge of the class of the truth of cessation.
Next, with regard to the realm of desire, there arises the patience that is knowledge of the truth of the path, called the patience of knowledge of the truth of the path.
Immediately after this patience, there arises knowledge of the truth of the path with regard to the realm of desire, called knowledge of the truth of the path.

Next, with regard to the realms of form and the formless realm, there arises the patience that is knowledge of the class of the truth of the path, called the patience of knowledge of the class of the truth of the path.
Immediately after this patience, there arises knowledge of the class of the truth of the path with regard to the same object, called knowledge of the class of the truth of the path.
In this way, there is a sequence of sixteen moments of mind, which in total are called insight into the holy truths.
In this matter, other schools say,
One only realizes the truths suddenly.
But the meaning of this must be investigated further, because the word realization is not distinguished.
In general, there are three kinds of realization, because there are differences of insight, object, and function.

Only pure wisdom that directly sees and clearly understands the four truths is called the insight of direct realization. The pure wisdom and the associated dharmas that have the same object are called the object of direct realization. The various means of knowing and the associated dharmas such as morality, the characteristics of birth, etc., that have the same function are called the function of direct realization.

When one sees the truth of suffering, one is endowed with the three direct realizations with regard to the holy truth of suffering, and only the function of direct realization with regard to the other three truths, i.e., one eliminates, realizes, and cultivates.

If, with regard to the various truths, one speaks of the direct realization of insight, then it is definitely not the case that one directly realizes them all at once, because the aspects of the various truths are different.

If it is said that one sees all the truths with the single aspect of no self, then one should not see the truth of suffering, etc., with the aspects of suffering, etc., and in this way one would contradict the scriptures.
As a scripture says,

The noble disciples contemplate suffering with the aspect of suffering, contemplate the cause with the aspect of cause, contemplate cessation with the aspect of cessation, and contemplate the path with the aspect of path, associated with the discernment of dharmas that is pure.
If it is said that this sÅ«tra speaks of the path of cultivation, this is also not so, because it is like seeing and cultivating.
If they further say that when one sees one truth, one attains mastery over the other truths, and therefore speaks of sudden realization, the principle is also not wrong.
However, one should carefully consider whether there is or is not arising in the midst of this realization.

If they further say that when seeing suffering one is able to eliminate the cause, realize cessation, and cultivate the path, and speak of sudden realization, the principle is also not wrong, because it has already been said that when seeing the truth of suffering, there is the realization of the other three truths.
Based on the realization of seeing, in the sÅ«tras there is clear evidence speaking of gradual realization.
As a sÅ«tra says:
The Buddha said to the elder:
One does not suddenly realize the four noble truths, but necessarily realizes them gradually, and so on at length.
There are three such sÅ«tras, each with a separate analogy.

If it is said that there is a sÅ«tra that says thus: One has no delusion or doubt regarding the truth of suffering, and also has none regarding the Buddha, therefore one suddenly realizes [the four noble truths].

We have explained the differences in the production of the paths of insight and cultivation. We must now establish the various holy beings in accordance with the differences in the stages of these paths.
First, in accordance with the fifteen moments of thought in the path of insight, we establish the differences in the holy beings. A verse says:
They are called followers of faith and followers of the dharma, distinguished by dullness and sharpness.
Endowed with the cultivation of the elimination of the passions, up to the elimination of five, they are heading for the first fruit.
Eliminating the next three, they head for the second. Free from the eighth stage, they head for the third.
The treatise says:

In the stage of the path of insight, there are two kinds of holy beings: followers of faith and followers of the dharma. The two names are established according to the distinction of dullness and sharpness. Those of dull faculties are called followers of faith, and those of sharp faculties are called followers of the dharma.
One who follows faith is called one who follows faith because he follows the path of insight by the power of faith in the teachings of another.
One who follows the Dharma is called one who follows the Dharma because he follows the path of insight by himself, through the power of contemplating the scriptures, etc.

These two, in the stage of the path of cultivation, are divided into three according to the differences in the degrees of elimination of the passions that are eliminated by cultivation. That is, if these two saints have not previously eliminated any of the passions that are eliminated by cultivation by means of the worldly path, they are called those bound by all bonds. If they have previously eliminated one to five categories of the passions of the realm of desire, they are called those approaching the first fruit, because they are approaching the first fruit.

If they have previously eliminated six, seven, or eight categories of the passions of the realm of desire, they are called those approaching the second fruit, because they are approaching the second fruit.
The second fruit is the fruit of once-returning, because it is the second fruit obtained.

If one has already been free from the nine grades of passions of the desire realm, or has already eliminated the first grade of passions of the first trance state, up to being completely free from the sphere of nothingness, at this stage one is called one who is heading for the third fruit, because one is heading for the third fruit.
The third fruit is the fruit of non-returning, which is explained by counting as before.
Next, based on the path of cultivation and the time of the cognition of the path, there are distinctions in the establishment of the various sages. The verse says:
Up to the sixteenth mind, following the three directions and abiding in the fruits,
Are called faith-understanding and view-attainment, also due to the distinctions of dull and sharp.
The treatise says:

Those who previously followed faith and those who followed the Dharma, up to the sixteenth mind of the cognition of the path of the noble ones, are called abiding in the fruits and are no longer called heading for the fruits.

The first three of these are the three fruits, because the former path of the candidate for the fruit of stream-winner is now the fruit of stream-winner, the former path of the candidate for the fruit of once-returner is now the fruit of once-returner, and the former path of the candidate for the fruit of non-returner is now the fruit of non-returner.

The fruit of arhat is never first acquired, because it is impossible for the path of insight to eliminate the passions that are to be eliminated by the path of cultivation, and it is impossible for the mundane path to eliminate the passions of the peak of existence.

When one reaches the state of abiding in the fruit, one abandons the two names of candidate for the fruit of stream-winner and candidate for the fruit of once-returner, and one acquires the two names of one who has attained the view of right faith and one who has attained by the power of insight. This is also due to the difference of dullness and sharpness of faculties.

Those of dull faculties are called those who have attained the view of right faith, and now they are called those who have attained by faith. Those of sharp faculties are called those who have attained by the power of insight, and now they are called those who have attained by the power of insight.

These two saints are distinguished by the names of those who have attained by faith and those who have attained by the power of insight because of the difference of the predominance of faith and the predominance of insight.

Why is it that when one first eliminates one to five categories of the passions of the realm of desire that are to be eliminated by cultivation, etc., up to the sixteenth mind of the path of insight into the single method of the class of the superior man, one is only said to be the fruit of stream-winner, etc., and not a candidate for the subsequent fruits?
The verse says:

The treatise says:

When one attains the fruit, one definitely has not yet attained the path of the superior fruit. Therefore, as long as one who abides in the fruit has not yet aroused the path of the superior fruit, one is only called one who abides in the fruit, not one who is progressing towards the subsequent fruit.

However, those who have previously severed one to five levels of the afflictions of the desire realm, when they attain the fruit, in this life they will definitely arouse the path of the superior fruit.

For this reason, those who have previously severed the defilements of the three meditations and later rely on the lower stages to enter the path of seeing, when they attain the fruit, in the present life they will definitely be able to induce the subsequent path of the superior fruit.
If it were otherwise, then the noble ones born in the upper stages would not be able to be said to definitely possess the faculty of pleasure.

In this way, based on those who are already endowed with the complete severance of the desire realm and the complete severance of the desire realm, and those who enter the path of seeing with the sixteen moments of mind, the distinctions among the various noble ones are established. Next, we will discuss the gradual arising of the counteracting paths that are able to eliminate the afflictions of the realm of form and the formless realm, and the distinctions in their stages.
A verse says:

Loss refers to faults, which are the obstacles to be eliminated.
Merits refer to the virtues, which are the path of elimination.
